enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Often used to list examples or to express a sense of 'and so forth', but with a slightly dismissive tone.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Overusing it can make conversations sound overly casual or sarcastic.
enhanced_notes.register: Casual; usage in formal settings or written language can be inappropriate.

examples.japanese: 私の家は火事で焼けてしまいました、家族の思い出の品はもう一つとしてありません
examples.romaji: Watashi no ie wa kaji de yakete shimaimashita, kazoku no omoide no shina wa mou hitotsu to shite arimasen
examples.english: My house has burned down in a fire, not even one of my family's keepsakes remains.

enhanced_notes.nuance: Expresses comprehensive negation of existence, often conveying strong personal sentiment.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Used with counter word and noun, often for inanimate objects or abstract concepts.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Incorrect counter word usage or placing the particle と where it doesn't belong.
enhanced_notes.register: Neutral–avoid using in especially polite or informal situations.

grammar.meaning: impression that; criticism/conclusion, this sort of thing

examples.japanese: 電車の中で眠っていて、財布を盗まれたなんて不注意と言うものだ
examples.romaji: Densha no naka de nemutte ite, saifu wo nusumareta nante fuchūi to iu mono da
examples.english: It's careless to fall asleep on a train and have your wallet stolen.

enhanced_notes.nuance: It emphasizes a general rule or phenomena based on the speaker's experience or observation, often with a negative critique.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Use after a verb in plain form; pay attention to nuance, as this shows a certain dissatisfaction or criticism.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Avoid using it to describe a specific one-time event, it's meant to describe habitual or general scenarios.
enhanced_notes.register: Common in both spoken and written Japanese, but usage can be more formal when written.

grammar.meaning: no guarantee that; not limited to

examples.japanese: 健康に気をつけている人がみんな長生きするとは限りません
examples.romaji: Kenkō ni ki o tsukete iru hito ga minna nagaiki suru to wa kagirimasen
examples.english: Not everyone who takes care of their health lives a long life.

enhanced_notes.nuance: 〜とは限らない carries an overtone of uncertainty or lack of assurance that the subject is exclusively as stated.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Use 〜とは限らない after the plain form of verbs, i-adjectives, or nouns to express the idea that something is not always the case.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Students often incorrectly link 〜とは限らない with na-adjectives, forgetting it requires aだorである before.
enhanced_notes.register: It is neutral in its social register, used in both informal and formal contexts.

grammar.meaning: together with; at the same time

examples.japanese: 毎年、冬休みは家族とともに過ごすことにしている
examples.romaji: Maitoshi, fuyuyasumi wa kazoku to tomo ni sugosu koto ni shite iru
examples.english: Every year, I make it a point to spend winter vacation with my family.

enhanced_notes.nuance: 〜とともに indicates simultaneity and also conveys a sense of correspondence or companionship.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Can be used with any verb, adjective or noun, but is often employed in formal or written context.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Avoid using 〜とともに when expressing negative events or situations, it is mostly used in neutral or positive contexts.
enhanced_notes.register: More formal and literary than casual spoken Japanese, suitable for professional or academic contexts.

examples.japanese: あまり行きたくないけど、先輩に誘われたら、行くしかないなあ
examples.romaji: Amari ikitakunai kedo, senpai ni sasowaretara, iku shika nai naa
examples.english: I don't really want to go, but if my senior invites me, I guess I have no choice.

enhanced_notes.nuance: 〜しかない conveys a sense of limitation or constraint and often includes a sense of regret, disappointment, or inevitability.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Combined with a negative verb, it emphasizes the scarcity or insufficiency of something; with positive verbs, it denotes exclusivity.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Often used incorrectly with positive verbs, or forgotten to negate the verb that follows.
enhanced_notes.register: Commonly used in both formal and informal contexts but may carry a pessimistic tone when used in casual conversation.

grammar.meaning: can't help but to ___; cannot resist

examples.japanese: 私は、新しいゲームが発売されると、買わないではいられません
examples.romaji: Watashi wa, atarashii gēmu ga hatsubai sareru to, kawanai de wa iraremasen
examples.english: Whenever a new game is released, I can't help but buy it.

examples.japanese: この国の日中はとても暑いので、昼寝をせずにはいられないそうです
examples.romaji: Kono kuni no nichū wa totemo atsui node, hirune o sezu ni wa irarenai sō desu
examples.english: It is said that it's so hot during the day in this country, one cannot help but take a nap.

enhanced_notes.nuance: 〜ではいられない implies a strong uncontrollable urge or necessity; it conveys feelings of desperation or lack of choice.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Attach ではいられない to negative ない-form of verbs to express 'can't help but do'.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Remember not to use で in positive statements. This form only works with negative verbs.
enhanced_notes.register: Usable in both casual and polite contexts; more frequently observed in written Japanese or formal speech.

grammar.notes: noun needs である, adjective can use な or である

examples.japanese: 東京の気候は、夏は蒸し暑い一方で、冬は乾燥する
examples.romaji: Tōkyō no kikō wa, natsu wa mushiatsui ippō de, fuyu wa kansō suru
examples.english: The climate in Tokyo is humid in the summer, while it is dry in the winter.

enhanced_notes.nuance: Indicates two contrasting or concurrent actions or states; often involves a negative implication or comparison.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Use after verbs in their dictionary form or 'na' adjectives/nouns + 'na', not suitable for 'i' adjectives.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Avoid using with 'i' adjectives; many learners mistakenly do so.
enhanced_notes.register: Fits typically in formal and written language, may sound unnatural in casual speech.

grammar.meaning: to be caused by; に is the causer

examples.japanese: カリフォルニアの火事になったと言うニュースに驚かされた
examples.romaji: Kariforunia no kaji ni natta to iu nyuusu ni odorokasareta
examples.english: I was surprised by the news that there was a fire in California

enhanced_notes.nuance: Used to express being affected by someone's action, often with a sense of trouble or inconvenience caused.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Commonly used with action verbs in the させられる form; don't use for physical phenomena or uncontrollable circumstances.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Mistaking させられる as passive voice; it's causative-passive and implies someone's action caused inconvenience.
enhanced_notes.register: Polite; consider social context and relationship with the 'causer' before usage.

grammar.notes: noun and adjective need である

examples.japanese: 環境問題は、この国のみならず、世界中の問題だ
examples.romaji: Kankyou mondai wa, kono kuni nominarazu, sekaijuu no mondai da
examples.english: Environmental issues are not only this country's problem, but a global issue.

examples.japanese: この辺りは駅から近くて便利であるのみならず、公園もあって住みやすい環境だ
examples.romaji: Kono atari wa eki kara chikakute benri de aru nomi narazu, kouen mo atte sumiyasui kankyo da
examples.english: Not only is this area convenient due to its proximity to the station, it also has a park and is a comfortable place to live.

enhanced_notes.nuance: はたらけどのみならず implies not only the mentioned situation, but also others of equal or greater importance, often enhancing contrast or surprise.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Similar to 'だけでなく', but adds a touch of emphasis or surprise; takes 普通形, noun and na-adjective as preceding elements.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Avoid overuse in colloquial speech as it gives a formal or written language feel. Don't use with い-adjectives.
enhanced_notes.register: Primarily used in formal, written, or academic language, less so in everyday spoken Japanese.

grammar.notes: noun and adjective need である

examples.japanese: 先生はチャイムと同時に、教室に入ってきた
examples.romaji: Sensei wa chaimu to douji ni, kyoushitsu ni haitte kita
examples.english: The teacher entered the classroom at the same time as the chime.

enhanced_notes.nuance: 〜と同時に indicates actions or states occurring concurrently, but often with a sense of surprise, or unexpectedness.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Used primarily with verbs; less commonly, but still acceptably, with na-adjectives and nouns.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Common mistake is to use it with i-adjectives, but this sentence form is not correct.
enhanced_notes.register: Used in both casual and formal, though slightly more common in formal or written language.

grammar.meaning: way; means of using something; via

examples.japanese: どのクラスに入るかはテストの結果によって決められます
examples.romaji: Dono kurasu ni hairu ka wa tesuto no kekka ni yotte kimeraremasu.
examples.english: Which class you are placed in is determined by the test results.

examples.japanese: 最近はメールやSNSなど、文字によるコミュニケーションが増えている
examples.romaji: Saikin wa mēru ya SNS nado, moji ni yoru komyunikēshon ga fuete iru
examples.english: Recently, there has been an increase in text-based communication such as emails and social networking sites.

enhanced_notes.nuance: 〜によって indicates the method or basis of action, often exhibiting variations based on context.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Not only for 'means' or methods, によって can also suggest a reason or a cause.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Avoid confusion with 〜による, which indicates a result, not a method or cause.
enhanced_notes.register: Appropriate for every social register, from casual to formal writing.

grammar.meaning: as expected, strong reason because (not resulting from quality or nature)
grammar.notes: noun and adjective can use な or である

examples.japanese: 一年間毎日頑張って勉強しただけに、合格できて本当に嬉しいです
examples.romaji: Ichinenkan mainichi ganbatte benkyou shita dake ni, goukaku dekite hontou ni ureshii desu
examples.english: I'm truly happy to have passed, especially because I worked hard and studied every day for a year.

examples.japanese: やっぱり連休中だけに、人がとても多かったよ
examples.romaji: Yappari renkyūchū dake ni, hito ga totemo ōkatta yo
examples.english: As I expected, just because it's a consecutive holidays, there were so many people.

enhanced_notes.nuance: 〜だけに expresses an expected outcome due to a strong reason, often causing a strong emotional reaction.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Use 〜だけに following nouns or na-adjectives in their dictionary form, or verbs in their plain form.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Not to be confused with だけで, which represents sufficiency, or だけど, extensive 'just' or 'simply'; だけに encapsulates higher stakes, expectations.
enhanced_notes.register: Frequently used in both formal and casual conversations, as well as in written Japanese.

examples.japanese: この大学に合格するのが難しいとしても、私はこの大学を受験したいです
examples.romaji: Kono daigaku ni gōkaku suru no ga muzukashii to shite mo, watashi wa kono daigaku o juken shitai desu.
examples.english: Even if it's difficult to pass this university, I want to take the entrance exam for this university.

examples.japanese: 遅れたとしても、連絡はくれるはずだよ
examples.romaji: Okureta to shite mo, renraku wa kureru hazu da yo
examples.english: Even if they are late, they should contact you.

enhanced_notes.nuance: Expresses the speaker's lack of expectation towards a hypothetical situation, often asserting an unfavorable or negative outcome.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Used after the plain form (普通形) of verbs, adjectives or with nouns, typically conjugated in the negative form to depict assumptions and contrasts.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Commonly mistaken with 〜たとしても; the usage differs as 〜としても works with non-past tenses while 〜たとしても focuses on finished actions.
enhanced_notes.register: Appropriate for both informal and formal registers; common in conversational and written Japanese.

examples.japanese: 遊園地の開業に先立って、オープニングイベントが行われます
examples.romaji: Yūenchi no kaigyō ni sakidatte, ōpuninguibento ga okonawaremasu
examples.english: An opening event will be held before the amusement park opens.

enhanced_notes.nuance: Imparts a formal, significant tone often used for events or proceedings.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Commonly used with important or ceremonial events, not everyday actions.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Using it for trivial or casual situations; pseudo-English 'prior to' can mislead.
enhanced_notes.register: Highly formal; used in business, coursework, newscasts, or formal writing.

grammar.meaning: if I had to say; if I had to pick something

examples.japanese: どちらかと言うと和食かなあ
examples.romaji: dochirakato iu to washoku kanaa
examples.english: If I had to choose, I'd probably say Japanese food.

examples.japanese: 今日は金曜日だし、どちらかというと、居酒屋に行きたいかな
examples.romaji: Kyou wa kinyoubi da shi, dochira ka to iu to, izakaya ni ikitai kana.
examples.english: Since today is Friday, I'd rather go to an izakaya, I guess.

enhanced_notes.nuance: Emphasizes one's preference or inclination when forced to choose between options, but suggests the choice isn't strong or decided.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Follow 'どちらかというと' immediately with the preferred choice out of two possibilities.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Don't imply a clear choice, this phrase relays a vague or weak preference.
enhanced_notes.register: Formal register; suitable for both writing and speech, but avoid using in highly casual contexts.

grammar.notes: noun and adjective can use な or である

examples.japanese: 彼女は歌手であるばかりでなく、有名な漫画家でもある
examples.romaji: Kanojo wa kashu de aru bakari de naku, yūmei na mangaka demo aru
examples.english: Not only is she a singer, but she is also a famous cartoonist.

enhanced_notes.nuance: This form emphasizes that the second element adds something unexpected or further important information after the first one.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Remember to use it after a noun or な-adjective in 終止形 mode for the second part.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Avoid using personal experiences and opinions; this grammar point is preferred for objective facts.
enhanced_notes.register: Prefers formal and written contexts; don't use it in casual or slangish expressions.

examples.japanese: やっと一つ仕事が終わったと思ったら、すぐ次の仕事を頼まれた
examples.romaji: Yatto hitotsu shigoto ga owatta to omottara, sugu tsugi no shigoto o tanomareta
examples.english: Just when I thought I had finally finished one job, I was asked to do the next one immediately

enhanced_notes.nuance: 〜かというと conveys a sense of surprise or change when an expected situation shifts suddenly.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Commonly used after a descriptive phrase in the past tense, it often includes a contrastive nuance.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Avoid using it in present or future tense as it is generally used to describe past situations.
enhanced_notes.register: Formal and informal contexts, but not recommended for highly formal settings or written language.

grammar.notes: must conjugate the adjective

examples.japanese: 彼は明日の面接試験でうまく話せるかどうか、不安でならない
examples.romaji: Kare wa ashita no mensetsu shiken de umaku hanaseru ka dou ka, fuan de naranai
examples.english: He cannot help but worry about whether he will be able to speak well in the interview tomorrow.

examples.japanese: この写真を見ると、昔のことが思い出されてならない
examples.romaji: Kono shashin o miru to, mukashi no koto ga omoidasarete naranai
examples.english: Looking at this picture, I can't help but reminisce about the past.

enhanced_notes.nuance: Expresses strong obligation or necessity, often associated with internal personal feelings or subjective desires.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Typically used with verbs in the て-form (テ形), to denote that the action can't/couldn't be helped.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Mistaking it as a negation structure, it doesn't negate the action it emphasizes its necessity.
enhanced_notes.register: Commonly used in informal conversation and self-expression, seldom used in formal or business settings.

grammar.meaning: its true that ___, but (uses same word in both spots)
grammar.notes: adjective and noun need the な

examples.japanese: インターネットは便利なことは便利だが、子供が使うには問題もある
examples.romaji: Intānetto wa benri na koto wa benri da ga, kodomo ga tsukau ni wa mondai mo aru
examples.english: While the internet is convenient, there are issues when it comes to usage by children.

examples.japanese: 行くことは行くけど、３０分ぐらい遅刻するかもしれない
examples.romaji: Iku koto wa iku kedo, sanjuppun gurai chikoku suru kamo shirenai.
examples.english: I will go, but I might be about 30 minutes late.

enhanced_notes.nuance: Expresses partial agreement, followed by contrasting information or an objection.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Following ことは, use non-past tense, applying negative form (〜ないことはないが) for denial translation.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Confusion arises from expecting entire sentence negation, instead of its partial or concessive negation nature.
enhanced_notes.register: More formal and written language; less commonly seen in casual speech.

examples.japanese: 年末年始は多くの会社が休みます、でも、会社によっては休みません
examples.romaji: Nenmatsunenshi wa ōku no kaisha ga yasumimasu, demo, kaisha ni yotte wa yasumimasen
examples.english: Many companies are closed for the year end and New Year holidays, but some companies do not close.

examples.japanese: 関東地方の人は納豆好きだが、人によっては納豆を見るのも嫌だと言う人もいる
examples.romaji: Kantō chihō no hito wa nattō suki da ga, hito ni yotte wa nattō o miru no mo iya da to iu hito mo iru
examples.english: People in the Kanto region tend to like natto, but there are also people who dislike even looking at natto.

enhanced_notes.nuance: Emphasizes variability depending on certain factors, often carries a sense of uncertainty.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Use before verb or noun phrases when conditions may alter an outcome.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Avoid using when conditions do not significantly change the result; not interchangeable with 'によると'.
enhanced_notes.register: Neutral to formal; commonly found in professional, academic, and legal contexts.

grammar.notes: noun and adjective need である

examples.japanese: 学校の代表として、スピーチコンテストに出場するからには、１位になりたい。
examples.romaji: Gakkō no daihyō to shite, supīchi kontesuto ni shutsujō suru kara ni wa, 1-i ni naritai.
examples.english: As a representative of my school, if I'm participating in a speech contest, I want to be first place.

examples.japanese: 約束したからは、守るのが当然だ。
examples.romaji: Yakusoku shita kara wa, mamoru no ga touzen da.
examples.english: Since I made a promise, it's only natural that I keep it.

enhanced_notes.nuance: 〜からには carries a sense of obligation or expectation upon the commencement of something or given a particular circumstance.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Use it with verbs in their Dictionary Form or nouns with 'na' or 'no' added before からには.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Avoid using it in past tense; it's mainly used with present and future contexts.
enhanced_notes.register: Mostly used in formal or written Japanese; can be too stiff for casual conversations.

grammar.notes: noun and adjective can use な or である

examples.japanese: 天気予報では晴れると言っていたのに、晴れるどころか大雨だ。
examples.romaji: Tenki yoho de wa hareru to itte ita noni, hareru dokoro ka ooame da.
examples.english: The weather forecast said it would be clear, but it's not just cloudy, it's pouring rain.

examples.japanese: 薬を飲んだのに、体調が良くなるどころか、もっと悪くなった。
examples.romaji: Kusuri o nonda noni, taichō ga yoku naru dokoroka, motto waruku natta.
examples.english: Despite taking the medicine, far from getting better, I felt even worse.

enhanced_notes.nuance: 「〜どころか」is used to highlight extreme contrast, stating that not only does A not apply, but more surprisingly, the opposite, B, is true.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Use this structure after a noun or na-adjective, and remember it emphasizes contrast in extreme terms, not mere comparison.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Avoid using 「どころか」after an i-adjective or verb; instead, use the plain form of nouns and na-adjectives.
enhanced_notes.register: While mostly used in written language or formal speech, it can occur in casual conversation when emphasizing a strong contrast.

grammar.meaning: can, can't (not based on personal abilities)

examples.japanese: 考え得る方法は全部やってみたけど、うまくいかなかった。
examples.romaji: Kangaeru hōhō wa zenbu yatte mita kedo, umaku ikanakatta.
examples.english: I tried every method I could think of, but none of them worked.

examples.japanese: 恋人と別れた時の気持ちは、どんな言葉を使っても、表し得ない。
examples.romaji: Koibito to wakareta toki no kimochi wa, donna kotoba o tsukatte mo, arawashi enai.
examples.english: The feelings when breaking up with a lover can't be expressed with any words.

enhanced_notes.nuance: Expresses a condition that is objectively possible or impossible.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Use 〜（える・えない） when talking about rules or laws, not personal abilities or talents.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Learners often confuse it with ことができる、which is for personal abilities.
enhanced_notes.register: Neutral form, used in both casual and formal situations.

grammar.meaning: not only, but also; not limited to

examples.japanese: 私はりんごに限らず、赤いならなんでも好きだ。
examples.romaji: Watashi wa ringo ni kagirazu, akai nara nandemo suki da.
examples.english: I like everything that's red, not just apples.

examples.japanese: 京都は休日に限らず、平日観光地が多い。
examples.romaji: Kyōto wa kyūjitsu ni kagirazu, heijitsu kankōchi ga ōi.
examples.english: Kyoto has many tourist destinations, not only on holidays but also on weekdays.

enhanced_notes.nuance: 〜限らず has a broader, open-ended implication, emphasizing that action or state is also applicable to others beyond what's stated.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Use 〜限らず after a noun to express more than the actual noun does, often with a feeling of inclusion.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Avoid using 〜限らず after verbs or adjectives, it's designed for nouns.
enhanced_notes.register: Typically used in formal or written contexts; tends to sound stiff in casual conversations.

examples.japanese: 田中さんは何か言いたげだったが、何も言わずに部屋を出て行った。
examples.romaji: Tanaka-san wa nanika iitageta ga, nanimo iwazu ni heya o dete itta.
examples.english: Tanaka seemed like he wanted to say something, but he left the room without saying a word.

examples.japanese: 面接試験の順番を待つ学生は、とても緊張して不安げだ。
examples.romaji: Mensetsu shiken no junban o matsu gakusei wa, totemo kinchou shite fuangeda.
examples.english: The student waiting for their turn in the interview exam looks very nervous and insecure.

enhanced_notes.nuance: 〜げ adds a touch of subjectivity, hinting at the speaker's perception or subtle feel about the situation.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Use it with non-i adjectives and na-adjectives; for verbs and i-adjectives, use 〜そう instead.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Don't use it with objective facts; it's only for subjective emotions or feelings.
enhanced_notes.register: Standard in spoken and written, informal to moderately formal contexts, but somewhat sensitive in highly formal or business-like communications.

grammar.meaning: the instant/moment that one thing happened

examples.japanese: 国の母に電話をかけた。母の声を聞いたとたんに、涙が出てきた。
examples.romaji: Kuni no haha ni denwa o kaketa. Haha no koe o kiita totan ni, namida ga detekita.
examples.english: I called my mother back in my home country. The moment I heard her voice, tears started to fall.

examples.japanese: テレビで紹介されて有名になったとたんに、お店のサービスが悪くなった。
examples.romaji: Terebi de shoukai sarete yuumei ni natta totan ni, omise no saabisu ga waruku natta.
examples.english: As soon as it was featured on TV and became famous, the service at the store worsened.

enhanced_notes.nuance: 〜とたんに (verb in past tense + to tan ni) conveys a sense of suddenness or immediacy, often coupled with surprise or unexpectedness.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Use this structure with verbs describing non-volitional actions or events. It is most commonly applied with actions that can't be controlled.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Avoid using volitional or intentional actions with this form. The event should be unexpected or sudden.
enhanced_notes.register: Formally and informally acceptable, it can be used smoothly in either spoken or written Japanese.

grammar.notes: adjective and noun need the な

examples.japanese: 東京はなんて人が多いんだろう。
examples.romaji: Tōkyō wa nante hito ga ōi ndarō.
examples.english: Tokyo sure has a lot of people.

examples.japanese: 初めてピザを食べた時はなんて美味しいんだろうと思いました。
examples.romaji: Hajimete piza o tabeta toki wa nante oishii n darou to omoimashita.
examples.english: When I ate pizza for the first time, I thought it was incredibly delicious.

enhanced_notes.nuance: An emphatic expression expressing surprise, awe or disbelief rather than a simple certainty.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Often used after な-adjectives and nouns, not typically used in formal writing.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Overuse can be perceived as melodramatic or insincere; not appropriate for all situations because of its strong nuance.
enhanced_notes.register: Used in personal and casual conversations, not suitable for professional or formal contexts.

examples.japanese: 私の人身事故以来、自転車に乗るのが怖くなった。
examples.romaji: Watashi no jinshin jiko irai, jitensha ni noru no ga kowaku natta.
examples.english: Ever since my personal accident, I've become scared of riding a bicycle.

examples.japanese: 日本へ来て以来、毎週ラーメンを食べている。
examples.romaji: Nihon e kite irai, mai shuu raamen o tabete iru.
examples.english: Since coming to Japan, I have been eating ramen every week.

enhanced_notes.nuance: Expresses continuous state or action from specified past point to present, often imbued with nostalgia or significant change.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: For verbs, always use the past tense (テ形) before 〜以来; for nouns, directly attach 〜以来.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Do not confuse with 〜から (from); 〜以来 implies no change since named event, 〜から stresses point of departure.
enhanced_notes.register: Neutral formality; used in both colloquial and written, formal contexts.

examples.japanese: 京都や日光と言った有名な観光地へ行ってみたい。
examples.romaji: Kyōto ya Nikkō to itta yūmei na kankōchi e itte mitai.
examples.english: I want to visit famous tourist destinations such as Kyoto and Nikko.

examples.japanese: 日本の会社では、トヨタやソニーと言った会社が有名です。
examples.romaji: Nihon no kaisha de wa, Toyota ya Sony to itta kaisha ga yuumei desu.
examples.english: In Japan, companies such as Toyota and Sony are famous.

enhanced_notes.nuance: Lists exhaustive or representative examples, but not always the only or best ones.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Often used in formal, academic or business context to mention examples without listing all.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Don't mistake it for exhaustive enumeration, it implies non-exclusivity of the items mentioned.
enhanced_notes.register: Neutral toward formal, not typically used in casual everyday speech.

examples.japanese: 私は日本のアニメを通して、日本人の生活や習慣を知りました。
examples.romaji: Watashi wa Nihon no anime o tooshite, Nihonjin no seikatsu ya shūkan o shirimashita.
examples.english: Through Japanese anime, I learned about the lifestyle and customs of the Japanese people.

examples.japanese: 旅行の前に、インタネットを通じて、宿泊するホテルを予約した。
examples.romaji: Ryokou no mae ni, intānetto o tsūjite, shukuhaku suru hoteru wo yoyaku shita.
examples.english: Before the trip, I booked a hotel to stay at through the internet.

enhanced_notes.nuance: Used to express a medium or method for action, not a route or path.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Link it directly to nouns that represent ways to achieve or do something.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Beware, not to be confused with the sense of going through a location.
enhanced_notes.register: Neutral and can be used in both formal and informal contexts.

examples.japanese: 私はこの街の歴史に関して図書館で調べてみた。
examples.romaji: Watashi wa kono machi no rekishi ni kanshite toshokan de shirabete mita.
examples.english: I tried researching the history of this city at the library.

examples.japanese: ビザや学費に関することは、学校の事務室に相談してください。
examples.romaji: Biza ya gakuhi ni kansuru koto wa, gakkou no jimushitsu ni soudan shite kudasai.
examples.english: Please consult with the school office regarding visa and tuition fees.

enhanced_notes.nuance: 〜関して implies a neutral stance with factual or practical discussions, not used for personal feelings or opinions.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Attach 〜関して directly to nouns or noun phrases; don't pair with verbs nor adjectives.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Avoid confusion with に関して as 〜関して is less formal; common misplacement of particle の before 〜関して.
enhanced_notes.register: Mostly found in written language and formal speech, not used frequently in casual conversation.

grammar.meaning: simply because, just because (not normal/bad result)
grammar.notes: noun needs である, adjective can use な or である

examples.japanese: この子は最近オスマートフォンがほしいばかりに、母親の財布からお金を盗んだ。
examples.romaji: Kono ko wa saikin osumatofon ga hoshii bakari ni, hahaoya no saifu kara okane o nusunda.
examples.english: This kid recently stole money from his mother's wallet because he wanted a smartphone so badly.

examples.japanese: 私は字が下手なばかりに、色々な場面で損をしている。
examples.romaji: Watashi wa ji ga heta na bakari ni, iroiro na bamen de son wo shite iru.
examples.english: Because my handwriting is so bad, it's caused me losses in various situations.

enhanced_notes.nuance: 〜ばかりに denotes a regrettable or negative outcome solely due to a certain reason, with an undertone of blaming or criticizing.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Attach 〜ばかりに after a dictionary form of a verb, an い-adjective, or a noun+の; do not use with a positive outcome.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Learners often misuse 〜ばかりに with positive results or without attributing negative or undesired consequences.
enhanced_notes.register: Commonly used in both formal and casual situations, but with a careful tone due to its negative implications.

grammar.meaning: as soon as, just as, right when this thing happened
grammar.notes: ナイ形 goes last

examples.japanese: バスが止まるが止まらないかのうちに席を立つ人が多い。
examples.romaji: Basu ga tomaru ga tomaranai ka no uchi ni seki o tatsu hito ga ooi.
examples.english: Many people stand up from their seats while the bus is still deciding whether to stop or not.

examples.japanese: 昨夜は疲れていたので、ベッドに横になったかならないかのうちに、眠ってしまった。
examples.romaji: Sakuya wa tsukarete ita node, beddo ni yoko ni natta ka naranai ka no uchi ni, nemutte shimatta.
examples.english: I was tired last night, so I fell asleep almost as soon as I lay in bed.

enhanced_notes.nuance: Indicates a specific moment or period when something changes; often conveys a feeling of time's fleeting nature.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Use after 辞書形, タ形, ナイ形 verbs; can be used with intransitive verbs to pinpoint a moment of change or transition.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Often confused with 〜たら for 'after'; differentiate by remembering 〜か〜かのうちに is 'just as/as soon as', not 'after'.
enhanced_notes.register: Neutral, can be used in both casual and formal contexts. Use with appropriate politeness level verb endings.

examples.japanese: 自分一人ではどうしていいかわからない時は、誰かに聞くことだよ。
examples.romaji: Jibun hitori de wa dou shite ii ka wakaranai toki wa, dareka ni kiku koto da yo.
examples.english: When you don't know what to do on your own, you should ask someone.

examples.japanese: 太りたくないなら、毎日散歩することだ。
examples.romaji: Futoritakunainara, mainichi sanpo suru koto da.
examples.english: If you don't want to gain weight, you should take a walk everyday.

enhanced_notes.nuance: 〜ことだ suggests a strong recommendation or advice, often implying a sense of urgency or importance.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Generally follows the dictionary or ない form of a verb; not used with です or ます verbs.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Misuse of tense continuity, i.e., using 〜ことだ in the past tense or with non-action verbs is incorrect.
enhanced_notes.register: Used in both casual and formal contexts, but sounds more authoritative or teacher-like.

grammar.usage: 〜（しかたがない・しょうがない）
grammar.notes: adjectives must be conjugated

examples.japanese: 日本へ来て、初めて一人暮らしをしているので、寂しくてしかたがない。
examples.romaji: Nihon e kite, hajimete hitori gurashi o shite iru node, sabishikute shikataganai.
examples.english: Since I came to Japan and started living alone for the first time, I can't help but feel lonely.

examples.japanese: ホームシックになってしまった。国の家族に会いたくてしようがない。
examples.romaji: Hōmushikku ni natte shimatta. Kuni no kazoku ni aitakute shiyō ga nai.
examples.english: I've become homesick. I desperately want to see my family back home.

enhanced_notes.nuance: Emotionally heavy phrase expressing helplessness or intense feelings.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Always use with negative verb form or adjective.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Avoid using with positive sentence structure, it invalidates the 'helplessness' context.
enhanced_notes.register: Casual conversation, narrative storytelling or self-reflection, not for formal settings.

grammar.meaning: instead of, substitute, the opposite also, this too
grammar.notes: noun needs である, adjective can use な or である

examples.japanese: 佐藤さんに日本語を教えてもらう代わりに、私は佐藤さんに英語を教えてあげる。
examples.romaji: Satō-san ni nihongo o oshiete morau kawarini, watashi wa Satō-san ni eigo o oshiete ageru.
examples.english: In exchange for Satou-san teaching me Japanese, I teach English to Satou-san.

examples.japanese: パソコンで書いた手紙は、文字が読みやすい代わりに、温かみがないように思います。
examples.romaji: Pasokon de kaita tegami wa, moji ga yomiyasui kawari ni, atatakami ga nai you ni omoimasu.
examples.english: I feel that letters written on a computer, while easier to read, lack a sense of warmth.

enhanced_notes.nuance: 〜ばかりに indicates a negative outcome due solely to a specific previous action, with a sense of blaming.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Use this pattern after verbs, 'i' adjectives, or 'na' adjectives in their plain forms.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Don't use 〜ばかりに interchangeably with 〜ばかりだ; they have different connotations.
enhanced_notes.register: Though not very colloquial, 〜ばかりに is not limited to formal contexts; can be used in casual speech.

grammar.usage: 〜（としたら・とすれば・とすると）
grammar.meaning: if it were the case that

examples.japanese: もし、ドキにでも旅行に行けるとしたら、どこへ行きたいですか
examples.romaji: Moshi, doko ni demo ryokou ni ikeru to shitara, doko e ikitai desu ka
examples.english: If you could go on a trip anywhere, where would you like to go?

enhanced_notes.nuance: Expresses supposition or hypothetical scenarios; often introduces a newfound realization or change of perspective.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Follows noun, adjective, or verb in plain form; not used when the assumption is highly likely to happen.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Mistakenly used in conditions guaranteed to happen; often confused with 〜と conditional which states a certain outcome.
enhanced_notes.register: Neutral, suitable in both casual conversation and formal writing.

examples.japanese: スピードを出しすぎると、事故を起こしかねない。
examples.romaji: Supīdo o dashi sugiru to, jiko o okoshi kanenai.
examples.english: If you go too fast, you could cause an accident.

examples.japanese: こんなに寒いところにいたら、風邪を引きかねない。
examples.romaji: Konna ni samui tokoro ni itara, kaze o hiki kanenai.
examples.english: If you stay in such a cold place, you might catch a cold.

enhanced_notes.nuance: Expresses fear, worry, or concern that something negative or undesirable might occur.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: This cannot be used to express positive predictions or possibilities, and is always attached to the stem of a verb.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Students often mistake ～かねない for a negated potential form, or wrongly use it for positive predictions.
enhanced_notes.register: Used in both, colloquial and formal speech, but seen more in written language, often in newspapers or reports.

grammar.usage: 〜（からでないと・からでなければ）

examples.japanese: 書類の内容を読んでから出ないと、印鑑を押すことはできません。
examples.romaji: Shorui no naiyou o yonde kara denai to, inkan o osu koto wa dekimasen.
examples.english: I cannot stamp the seal until I read the content of the document.

examples.japanese: 私の国では、２０歳になってからでなければ、お酒を飲むことができません。
examples.romaji: Watashi no kuni de wa, nijuu sai ni natte kara de nakereba, osake o nomu koto ga dekimasen.
examples.english: In my country, you cannot drink alcohol until you turn 20.

enhanced_notes.nuance: Emphasizes a strong condition that MUST be met; slightly formal and dramatic.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Commonly used with actions the speaker wishes to emphasize as necessary or important to achieve a certain goal.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Learners often confuse this with 'から' alone, but adding 'でないと/でなければ' makes it conditional; essential to complete the action, event, or state.
enhanced_notes.register: More suited to written language, speeches, or formal situations; too formal for intimate and casual conversations.

grammar.meaning: wan't to but cant for some reason

examples.japanese: ちょっと眠いけど、今は授業中なので寝るわけにはいかない。
examples.romaji: Chotto nemui kedo, ima wa jugyōchū nanode neru wake ni wa ikanai.
examples.english: I'm a bit sleepy, but I can't sleep because I'm in class right now.

enhanced_notes.nuance: Expresses a strong sense of obligation, social or personal pressure, or an action that shouldn't be done for various reasons.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Use with dictionary form or 'nai' form of verbs, indicating a desired action that is not undertaken due to some constraint.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Often mistaken with 'cannot do' due to physical inability, 'わけにはいかない' is about situations where one might want to, but can't due to social or moral reasons.
enhanced_notes.register: Common in both casual and formal situations, but tends to be avoided in highly formal or written language due to its subjective emotionality.

examples.japanese: 子供の頃は、よく甘いものを食べたものだ。
examples.romaji: Kodomo no koro wa, yoku amai mono o tabeta mono da.
examples.english: When I was a child, I used to eat sweets quite often.

examples.japanese: 国ではよく友達とサッカをしたものだ。
examples.romaji: Kuni de wa yoku tomodachi to sakka o shita mono da.
examples.english: I used to often play soccer with my friends in my country.

enhanced_notes.nuance: Expresses past habit or state, usually nostalgic or somewhat regretful.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Attach to verb's past-form (タ形), doesn't work with past negatives.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Avoid using it for routine or recurring past actions (そうだ used instead).
enhanced_notes.register: Standard and casual, often seen in spoken language and personal narratives.

grammar.meaning: when it comes to ___, ___　(focus on ability and higher than others)

examples.japanese: かんさんは人を笑わせることにかけては、クラスで一番だ。
examples.romaji: Kansan wa hito wo warawaseru koto ni kakete wa, kurasu de ichiban da.
examples.english: When it comes to making people laugh, Kansan is the best in the class.

enhanced_notes.nuance: 〜にかけては underlines a speaker's emphasis or slightly competitive sense of superiority on a certain topic or ability.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Use 〜にかけては after a subject or topic, to express its superiority or excellence in the following context.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Often mistakenly used to compare two equal topics instead of emphasizing the superiority of one.
enhanced_notes.register: Formal and casual, but somewhat assertive, often used in debates, arguments, or playful competitions.

examples.japanese: このシャツはデザインはともかくとして、色があまり好きじゃない。
examples.romaji: Kono shatsu wa dezain wa tomokaku toshite, iro ga amari suki janai.
examples.english: Regardless of the design, I don't really like the color of this shirt.

enhanced_notes.nuance: 〜はともかく（として）can indicate a dismissive or neutral attitude toward the first mentioned item while focusing on the latter.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Use it to distinguish between two subjects or ideas, typically setting the first aside to focus on the second.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Don't mix this up with 〜はもちろん（which stresses the importance of the first item); 〜はともかく downplays the first item's importance.
enhanced_notes.register: Mostly used in casual and informal speech, occasionally in formal written texts.

grammar.notes: must conjugate the adjective and noun with く and で

examples.japanese: 新宿からなら歩けないことはないけど、大変だよ。
examples.romaji: Shinjuku kara nara arukenai koto wa nai kedo, taihen da yo.
examples.english: It's not impossible to walk from Shinjuku, but it's tough.

examples.japanese: 時間をもらえれば、やれないことはないと思います。
examples.romaji: Jikan o moraereba, yarenai koto wa nai to omoimasu.
examples.english: If given the time, I believe there's nothing I cannot do.

enhanced_notes.nuance: Conveys reluctant agreement or admits a possibility, but with reservation or unenthusiastic tone.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Often used to soften 'yes', but implies doubt or presents the 'yes' as the less preferable choice.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Don't overuse or use for strong agreement; it's better suited for subtler nuances of agreement with reservation.
enhanced_notes.register: Informal and conversational; may sound evasive or noncommittal in formal settings.

examples.japanese: 父は酒も飲めば、とばこも吸うので、体を壊さないか心配です。
examples.romaji: Chichi wa sake mo nomeba, tabako mo suu node, karada o kowasanai ka shinpai desu.
examples.english: I'm worried that my father might ruin his health because he both drinks alcohol and smokes tobacco.

examples.japanese: 人生には山もあれば、谷もある。
examples.romaji: Jinsei ni wa yama mo areba, tani mo aru.
examples.english: Life has its peaks and valleys.

enhanced_notes.nuance: 「N」も〜「N」も is used to express multiple actions on the same topic and shows that both parts have equal weight.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Use the pattern when you want to emphasize the equalness of two or more nouns or noun phrases.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Do not use with only one noun, and never mix 'と' and 'も' in the same context.
enhanced_notes.register: Neutral, commonly used in both written and spoken Japanese.

grammar.usage: 〜（にわたって・にわたる・にわたる「N」）

examples.japanese: この店は５０年にわたって、伝統の味を守り続けている。
examples.romaji: Kono mise wa 50 nen ni watatte, dentou no aji o mamori tsuzukete iru.
examples.english: This shop has been preserving its traditional flavors for over 50 years.

examples.japanese: ４時間にわたる会議がやっと終わりました。
examples.romaji: yon-jikan ni wataru kaigi ga yatto owari mashita.
examples.english: The meeting that lasted for four hours has finally ended.

enhanced_notes.nuance: Expresses the concept of something spanning or extending over a certain period or area.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Use にわたって for actions/changes over time, にわたる modifies a noun, and Noun + にわたる for 'throughout N'.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Avoid using with instantaneous actions; rather, use for ongoing processes or changes.
enhanced_notes.register: Neutral, can be used in both casual and formal contexts.

examples.japanese: ５００ページもある本を１日で読み切るなんて無理です。
examples.romaji: Go hyaku peeji mo aru hon o ichinichi de yomikiru nante muri desu.
examples.english: It's impossible to finish reading a 500-page book in one day.

examples.japanese: こんなにたくさんの料理、私一人では食べきれない。
examples.romaji: Konna ni takusan no ryouri, watashi hitori de wa tabekirenai.
examples.english: I can't finish all this food by myself.

enhanced_notes.nuance: Expresses an extent or limit, often indicating a state of completion, capacity, or inability.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Often used with verbs of perception, understanding, consumption; in the negative form, indicates incapability or lack of capacity.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Not to be used with verbs expressing continuous or habitual actions, or ones that can't represent a finite quantitative limit.
enhanced_notes.register: Common in both casual and polite speech, but it's more frequent in written language or formal conversations.

grammar.notes: noun and adjective need である

examples.japanese: 今日は結婚する日であるにもかかわらず、田中さんはあまり嬉しそうに見えない。
examples.romaji: Kyou wa kekkon suru hi de aru ni mo kakawarazu, Tanaka-san wa amari ureshisou ni mienai.
examples.english: Despite today being his wedding day, Mr. Tanaka doesn't seem very happy.

examples.japanese: 家族が反対したにもかかわらず、彼は軍に入会する。
examples.romaji: Kazoku ga hantai shita ni mo kakawarazu, kare wa gun ni nyuukai suru.
examples.english: Despite his family's opposition, he joined the military.

enhanced_notes.nuance: Used to express strong contrast, can carry a sense of dissatisfaction or surprise.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Paste directly after nouns, na-adjectives, or verbs in dictionary/plain forms.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Don't follow it with verb in negative form, that changes the meaning.
enhanced_notes.register: Flexibly utilized in casual, formal, written, or spoken language.

grammar.usage: 〜（からいうと・からいって・からいえば）

examples.japanese: 値段から言うと、単品料理をたくさん頼むより、コース料理の方がお得だ。
examples.romaji: Nedan kara iu to, tanpin ryouri o takusan tanomu yori, koosu ryouri no hou ga otoku da.
examples.english: Judging from the price, it's more economical to order a course meal than to order many individual dishes.

examples.japanese: 実力から言って、この大会ではブラジルが優勝するだろう。
examples.romaji: Jitsuryoku kara itte, kono taikai de wa Burajiru ga yūshō suru darou.
examples.english: Judging by their ability, Brazil will probably win this tournament.

examples.japanese: 品質から言えば、これが一番いいけれど、こんなに高いものは私には買えない。
examples.romaji: Shitsu kara ieba, kore ga ichiban ii keredo, konna ni takai mono wa watashi ni wa kaenai.
examples.english: In terms of quality, this is the best, but it's so expensive that I can't afford it.

enhanced_notes.nuance: Used to qualify a statement within a specific context, often for comparison, evaluation, or preparing for a contrasting idea.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Commonly used in written form or formal speaking, and comes after the topic of consideration.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Learners often forget that 〜（からいうと・からいって・からいえば）requires a subject or topic to 'speak in terms of', and may incorrectly use it in casual conversations.
enhanced_notes.register: Commonly used in formal or academic contexts.

grammar.usage: 〜（となると・となれば・となったら）
grammar.notes: noun and adjective need the だ

examples.japanese: 今買い物をすると８％の税金がかかる。これが１０％に上がるとなれば、国民の生活はさらに大変になるだろう。
examples.romaji: Ima kaimono o suru to hachi pāsento no zeikin ga kakaru. Kore ga jyu pāsento ni agaru to nareba, kokumin no seikatsu wa sarani taihen ni naru darō.
examples.english: Currently, an 8% tax is imposed when you shop. Should this rise to 10%, people's lives will likely become even more difficult.

examples.japanese: 早く国へ帰りたいと思っているが、本当に帰国するとなったら、寂しさを感じるかもしれない。
examples.romaji: Hayaku kuni e kaeritai to omotte iru ga, hontou ni kikoku suru to nattara, sabishisa o kanjiru kamo shirenai.
examples.english: I'm thinking about wanting to go back to my country soon, but if I really do go back, I might feel lonely.

enhanced_notes.nuance: Emphasizes change of state or condition, often implying unforeseen circumstances or surprise.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Use with nouns and na-adjectives, and in contexts where a speaker discusses a hypothetical situation.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Don't use if not referring to a situation that prompts change or causes surprise.
enhanced_notes.register: Neutral to formal, suitable for a range of contexts, from conversation to written communication.

examples.japanese: 明日のイベントに行くかどうかは、天気次第です。
examples.romaji: Ashita no ibento ni iku ka dou ka wa, tenki shidai desu.
examples.english: Whether or not I'll go to the event tomorrow depends on the weather.

examples.japanese: やる気次第で、うまく行くかどうかは決まると思う。
examples.romaji: Yaruki shidai de, umaku iku ka dou ka wa kimaru to omou.
examples.english: I think whether things go well or not depends on your motivation.

enhanced_notes.nuance: 〜次第だ implies causality but also a degree of helplessness or inevitability, often used when 'things are as they are' due to circumstances beyond control.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: It is usually used with nouns to add contextual reasons influencing the current situation.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Incorrect replacement of ~次第だ with other causal/conditional clauses (あげく、ため) due to similar meanings but different emotional contexts.
enhanced_notes.register: Mostly used in a formal, polite, or written context, less common in informal or casual speech.

examples.japanese: どんな苦しくても途中で諦めない。最後までやり抜くつもりだ。
examples.romaji: Donna kurushikute mo tochuu de akiramenai. Saigo made yarinuku tsumori da.
examples.english: No matter how tough it gets, I won't give up halfway. I intend to see it through to the end.

examples.japanese: 祖父は戦後の苦しい時代を何とか生き抜く、今は孫に囲まれる幸せに暮らしている。
examples.romaji: Sofu wa sengo no kurushii jidai o nantoka ikinuku, ima wa mago ni kakomare shiawase ni kurashite iru.
examples.english: My grandfather, who somehow survived the difficult post-war era, now lives happily surrounded by his grandchildren.

enhanced_notes.nuance: The 〜ぬく ending express a sense of strong determination to finish/completeness, or mandates a task be done thoroughly.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Most commonly used with verbs that express continuous or repeated action (ex: 読む → 読みぬく).
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Not to be confused with the negative form 'ぬ', nor should it be used with instantaneous, one-time actions.
enhanced_notes.register: Considered literary or old-fashioned language, so it is often found in written texts or formal settings.

examples.japanese: 古い友人たちと酒を飲みつつ、学生時代の懐かしい話をした。
examples.romaji: Furui yuujin-tachi to sake o nomitsutsu, gakusei jidai no natsukashii hanashi o shita.
examples.english: While drinking booze with old friends, we talked about fond memories from our student days.

examples.japanese: 結婚するのことは恋人と相談しつつ、決めるつもりだ。
examples.romaji: Kekkon suru no koto wa koibito to soudan shitsutsu, kimeru tsumori da.
examples.english: I intend to decide on getting married while consulting with my partner.

enhanced_notes.nuance: 〜つつ expresses two events happening simultaneously but conveys a sense of ongoing action or change.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Attach 〜つつ to the stem of verbs, not to conjugated forms.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Avoid using with actions which don't logically occur at the same time.
enhanced_notes.register: Generally neutral, found in both casual and formal contexts, but more common in written Japanese or formal speech.

examples.japanese: あの人会ったのは一回きりだから、まだどんな人かはよくわからない。
examples.romaji: Ano hito atta no wa ikkai kiri dakara, mada donna hito ka wa yoku wakaranai.
examples.english: I've only met that person once, so I still don't really know what they're like.

examples.japanese: クリスマスを一人きりですごそのは本当に寂しいものだ。
examples.romaji: Kurisumasu o hitori kiri de sugosu no wa hontō ni sabishii mono da.
examples.english: Spending Christmas alone is truly a lonely thing.

enhanced_notes.nuance: Emphasizes the limit or an unchanging state since a certain point; signifies disappointment or dissatisfaction.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Use after a verb stem or a noun; it cannot modify adjectives directly.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Don't confuse it with ~(だ)け for quantifying; ~(っ)きり also implies a negative emotional context.
enhanced_notes.register: Common in spoken and written language; slightly informal.

examples.japanese: 病気になって初めて、家族の大切さがわかった。
examples.romaji: Byouki ni natte hajimete, kazoku no taisetsu-sa ga wakatta.
examples.english: It was only after I fell ill that I understood the importance of family.

examples.japanese: 一人暮らしになって初めて、母親のありがたさがわかった。
examples.romaji: Hitorigurashi ni natte hajimete, hahaoya no arigatasaga wakatta.
examples.english: It was only when I started living alone that I truly appreciated my mother.

enhanced_notes.nuance: Emphasizes the 'first time' something is experienced, done, or observed; can highlight unexpectedness.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Place the verb directly before 初めて, or use between two verb phrases to denote 'for the first time after'.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Don't confuse 初めて (first time) with 始めて (to begin) due to pronunciation. Misplacement in sentence is common.
enhanced_notes.register: Neutral, used freely in both casual and formal situations.

grammar.notes: noun and adjective need である

examples.japanese: 漢字を習ったと言っても、１００字ぐらい覚えたにすぎない。
examples.romaji: Kanji o naratta to itte mo, hyakuji gurai oboeta ni suginai.
examples.english: Even though I said I learned kanji, I only remember about 100 characters.

examples.japanese: ドイツ語がわかると言っても、日常会話んみすぎません。
examples.romaji: Doitsugo ga wakaru to itte mo, nichijou kaiwa nomi sugimasen.
examples.english: Even though I say I understand German, it doesn't go beyond daily conversation.

enhanced_notes.nuance: Expresses a limitation or minimal status, often with a dismissive too; may imply disappointment or underachievement.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Pairs with nouns, verbs (in dictionary form), and na-adjectives; does not work with i-adjectives.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Learners frequently neglect the negative connotation, or misuse it with i-adjectives.
enhanced_notes.register: Neutral to formal; found in written language and formal conversations.

examples.japanese: 留学にあたって、必要な書類を準備しました。
examples.romaji: Ryūgaku ni atatte, hitsuyōna shorui o junbi shimashita.
examples.english: In preparation for studying abroad, I have prepared the necessary documents.

examples.japanese: 帰国するにあたって、先生のところへ挨拶に行った。
examples.romaji: Kikoku suru ni atatte, sensei no tokoro e aisatsu ni itta.
examples.english: Before returning to my home country, I went to greet my teacher.

enhanced_notes.nuance: 〜にあたって (when doing this) express a formal, planned occurrence that is important or significant.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Use 〜にあたって with the dictionary form of verbs for significant/important tasks or events in settings that are formal or serious.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Do not use 〜にあたって for casual, everyday actions/events or spontaneous occurrences - this is a common mistake.
enhanced_notes.register: This is formal and mostly used in written language or formal speech.

examples.japanese: コンビニは昼夜を問わず、営業しています。
examples.romaji: Konbini wa chuuya o towazu, eigyo shiteimasu.
examples.english: Convenience stores are open day and night, regardless of time.

examples.japanese: 北海度は季節を問わず、多くの観光客で賑わっています。
examples.romaji: Hokkaidō wa kisetsu o towazu, ōku no kankōkyaku de nigiwatte imasu.
examples.english: Hokkaido is bustling with many tourists, regardless of the season.

enhanced_notes.nuance: The phrase ～を問わず possesses a rather formal and cold tone, marking an impersonal and broad sweeping categorization.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Use it after nouns to convey 'regardless of'; e.g., 年齢を問わず (regardless of age).
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Often misused to express preference or abstract statements, but is intended to express the lack of discrimination between concrete categories or options.
enhanced_notes.register: Formal written language; less common but still acceptable in spoken language - considered business-like or bureaucratic.

grammar.meaning: when; upon (not after); in that exact moment
grammar.notes: noun needs the の

examples.japanese: 仕事を進める上で、みんなの協力が必要だ。
examples.romaji: Shigoto o susumeru ue de, minna no kyōryoku ga hitsuyō da.
examples.english: In progressing with work, everyone's cooperation is necessary.

examples.japanese: 共同生活をする上で大切なのは、お互いにルールを守ることです。
examples.romaji: Kyōdō seikatsu o suru ue de taisetsu na no wa, otagai ni rūru o mamoru koto desu.
examples.english: In communal living, it's important to respect each other's rules.

enhanced_notes.nuance: Expresses a condition that needs to be met before starting something else, rather than indicating immediate sequence in time series.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Use with 辞書形 (dictionary form) of verbs and nouns, often used with major decisions or actions.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Easily confused with 〜後で; think conditional, not temporal, it doesn't replace after or before.
enhanced_notes.register: Formal and professional, frequently seen in business situations or official writing.

grammar.meaning: while; on the other hand (can't be too opinionated?)
grammar.notes: noun needs である, adjective can use な or である

examples.japanese: 就職活動は準備が大変である反面、自分自身を知るチャンスでもある。
examples.romaji: Shūshoku katsudō wa junbi ga taihen de aru hanmen, jibun jishin o shiru chansu demo aru.
examples.english: While job hunting is challenging in terms of preparation, it also offers an opportunity to know oneself.

examples.japanese: スマートフォンは日本語を勉強のために便利な反面、ストレスを与える道具でもある。
examples.romaji: Sumātofon wa nihongo o benkyō no tame ni benri na hantai-men, sutoresu o ataeru dōgu de mo aru.
examples.english: While smartphones are convenient for studying Japanese, they can also be a source of stress.

enhanced_notes.nuance: 〜反面 contrasts two sides of a situation, often revealing an unexpected or paradoxical aspect.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Attach 〜反面 to dictionary form of verbs, na-adjectives with a 'na', and nouns.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Don't use with i-adjectives, or to express personal opinions.
enhanced_notes.register: Neutral to formal register, often used in written language and formal speech.

grammar.meaning: is more of a; or perhaps I should say; rather than
grammar.notes: noun and adjective need the だ

examples.japanese: 元気というか、うるさいよ。
examples.romaji: Genki to iu ka, urusai yo.
examples.english: You're not just lively, you're loud.

enhanced_notes.nuance: Expresses hesitation or correction, adding a softer or more indirect tone to what's being said.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Used after stating something to revise or reconsider it; often used with the plain form of adjectives and verbs.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Don't use it in questions or negative sentences; it's not for contrasts between two completely different things.
enhanced_notes.register: Casual, colloquial speech or informal writing; seen as a tad indirect.

grammar.notes: noun and adjective need である

examples.japanese: 試合に出場する以上、絶対勝ってみせる。
examples.romaji: Shiai ni shutsujou suru ijou, zettai katte miseru.
examples.english: Now that I'm taking part in the match, I'll definitely show you a win.

examples.japanese: 書類にサインした以上は、キャンセルはできません。
examples.romaji: Shorui ni sain shita ijou wa, kyanseru wa dekimasen.
examples.english: Once you've signed the documents, you cannot cancel.

enhanced_notes.nuance: ～以上は/上は suggests a causality, but carries a stronger, more set tone, expressing a situation that must be done/must be so because the condition is set (above this point).
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Often used in formal statements or decisions; usually after dictionary form or na-adjective/noun with 'である'.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: The mistake is to interchange/confuse with 以上 (meaning more than or not less than); this 以上 is different, with the meaning of 'since' or 'now that'.
enhanced_notes.register: More towards formal and written Japanese; sometimes seen in formal speeches.

grammar.meaning: as long as; while; to the limit possible
grammar.notes: nouns need the の

examples.japanese: 難民たちは持てる限りの荷物を持って、逃げてきた。
examples.romaji: Nanmin-tachi wa moteru kagiri no nimotsu o motte, nigete kita.
examples.english: The refugees came fleeing with as much luggage as they could carry.

examples.japanese: 映画が好きなので、時間とお金の許す限り、映画館へ見に行っています。
examples.romaji: Eiga ga suki na node, jikan to okane no yurusu kagiri, eigakan e mi ni itte imasu.
examples.english: Because I like movies, I go to the cinema to watch them as much as my time and money allow.

enhanced_notes.nuance: Unable to generate detailed notes

examples.japanese: もう少しゆっくり話していただけないでしょうか。
examples.romaji: Mou sukoshi yukkuri hanashite itadakenai deshou ka?
examples.english: Could you speak a little slower, please?

examples.japanese: アンケートに協力していただけないでしょうか。
examples.romaji: Ankeeto ni kyouryoku shite itadakenai deshou ka?
examples.english: Could you possibly assist with the survey?

enhanced_notes.nuance: 〜いただけないでしょうか expresses a polite and somewhat indirect request, often signaling humility.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Use this grammar when asking for favors from superiors or in formal settings; remember it contains the verb ‘to receive’ (いただく), not ‘to give’.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Avoid using it with close friends or in casual situations; wrong use of politeness level can sound mechanical or distant.
enhanced_notes.register: Used in professional or formal conversations to convey respect or subordination.

grammar.meaning: while I'm interrupting; I'm sorry but
grammar.notes: nouns need the の, noun adjective needs the な

examples.japanese: もしもし、先生、お休みのところ、お電話してすみません。実は。。。
examples.romaji: Moshimoshi, sensei, o-yasumi no tokoro, o-denwa shite sumimasen. Jitsu wa...
examples.english: Hello, teacher, I'm sorry to call you during your break. Actually...

enhanced_notes.nuance: Used to preface an interruption or show regret for inconvenience caused, often creates a light apologetic tone.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Commonly used with verbs in the te-form or nouns indicating an action, not usually with adjectives.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Learners often use it as a casual phrase, failing to recognize its formal and somewhat apologetic connotations.
enhanced_notes.register: Polite and formal; used in situations requiring social etiquette.

grammar.meaning: was wondering if you could help

examples.japanese: 大学の資料を見せていただけないかと思って。。。
examples.romaji: Daigaku no shiryou wo misete itadakenai ka to omotte...
examples.english: I was wondering if you could show me some materials from the university...

examples.japanese: 次の説明会の予定を教えていただけないかと思って。。。
examples.romaji: Tsugi no setsumeikai no yotei o oshiete itadakenai ka to omotte...
examples.english: I was wondering if you could let me know the schedule for the next informational meeting...

enhanced_notes.nuance: Expresses a respectful and indirect request; carries a tone of apprehensiveness and consideration toward the listener's situation.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Use it when asking for a favor in a polite way, especially from superiors or people you don't know well.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Don't use it for casual or informal situations; this could come off as too formal and distant.
enhanced_notes.register: Used in formal/semi-formal situations, professional settings, and in conversations with superiors or unfamiliar people.

examples.japanese: 体に悪いと知りつつ、つい一体タバコを吸ってしまう。
examples.romaji: Karada ni warui to shiritsutsu, tsui ittai tabako o sutte shimau.
examples.english: Even though I know it's bad for my health, I end up smoking a cigarette anyway.

examples.japanese: 友達と遊びたいと思いつつも、忙しくてその暇がない。
examples.romaji: Tomodachi to asobitai to omotsutsu mo, isogashikute sono hima ga nai.
examples.english: Even though I want to hang out with my friends, I'm too busy to find the time.

enhanced_notes.nuance: 〜つつも conveys a contrast between the ongoing action and the unexpected or contradicting circumstance.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Use 〜つつも after the ます-stem of a verb to express 'despite doing' or 'even while doing'.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Avoid using 〜つつも with actions that aren't continuous, as it implies an ongoing action.
enhanced_notes.register: 〜つつも leans toward formal and literary contexts; not commonly used in everyday, casual speech.

grammar.meaning: leaving something as; casually negative statement

examples.japanese: 誰もいないのに、電気もエアコンも付けっぱなしだ。
examples.romaji: Daremo inai noni, denki mo eakon mo tsukeppanashi da.
examples.english: Even though there's no one around, both the lights and the air conditioner have been left on.

examples.japanese: 窓を開けっぱなしで寝たので、風邪をひいてしまいました。
examples.romaji: Mado wo akeppanashi de neta node, kaze wo hiite shimaimashita.
examples.english: Because I slept with the window open, I ended up catching a cold.

enhanced_notes.nuance: 〜っぱなし indicates something left in a certain state, usually uncared for, and carries a sense of frustrative negativity.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Use after the stem of verb, usually for actions undesirably incomplete or states uncorrected over a period of time.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Learners often misapply it to non-action verbs or use it without negative connotations which is typically incorrect.
enhanced_notes.register: Common in spoken language, informal dialogues and casual settings, not used in formal writing or speech.

examples.japanese: 初めてマラソン大会に出場したが、途中で一度も止まるこたなく、走り抜いた。
examples.romaji: Hajimete marathon taikai ni shutsujou shita ga, tochuu de ichido mo tomaru koto naku, hashiri nuita.
examples.english: It was my first time participating in a marathon, but I managed to run all the way without stopping even once.

examples.japanese: 彼は何度失敗しても構うことなく、のんびりする。
examples.romaji: Kare wa nando shippai shite mo kamau koto naku, nonbiri suru.
examples.english: He doesn't mind how many times he fails, he takes it easy.

enhanced_notes.nuance: Expresses the idea of 'not doing something even once'; often used to emphasize surprising or exceptional cases.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Use with verbs in their dictionary form; don't use with potential or passive verbs.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Learners often forget that 'ことなく' attaches to the dictionary form of verbs, and mistakenly use it with the negative verb form.
enhanced_notes.register: Formal, often used in written language or formal speech.

grammar.meaning: in addition to; as well as
grammar.notes: noun needs である or の, adjective can use な or である

examples.japanese: この会社は給料が高い上に、休みも多い。
examples.romaji: Kono kaisha wa kyuuryou ga takai ue ni, yasumi mo ooi.
examples.english: This company not only pays well, but also provides a lot of days off.

examples.japanese: このレストランは安い上に、美味しいので、いつも混んでいる。
examples.romaji: Kono resutoran wa yasui ue ni, oishii node, itsumo konde iru.
examples.english: This restaurant is not only cheap, but also delicious, so it's always crowded.

enhanced_notes.nuance: 〜上に often carries a sense of unexpectedness and intensity, amplifying the situation with the additional fact provided.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Commonly used with negative sentences or unexpected situations, but can also be used with positive situations.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Often mistaken as only for negative points or misunderstood as an 'on top of that' structure. Make sure the main clause and the 〜上に clause are logically connected.
enhanced_notes.register: Mixture of casual and formal, but often seen informally in conversation.

examples.japanese: この山はそんなに高くないし、日帰りで行けるので、登山の初心者向きだ。
examples.romaji: Kono yama wa sonna ni takakunai shi, higaeri de ikeru node, tozan no shoshinsha muki da.
examples.english: This mountain is not so high and can be done in a day trip, so it's suitable for beginner climbers.

examples.japanese: ここは独身者向きのマンションで家族で住むには狭いようだ。
examples.romaji: Koko wa dokushinsha muki no manshon de kazoku de sumu ni wa semai you da.
examples.english: This seems like a condominium suited for single individuals; it appears too narrow for family living.

enhanced_notes.nuance: Use this to express the idea of suitability in a subjective and sometimes situational way.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Attach 向き directly to nouns, but only when describing objects or situations, not living creatures.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Common mistakes include employing it for humans, which sounds odd, and confusing 向き with 向け.
enhanced_notes.register: Commonly used in informal contexts or professional settings.

examples.japanese: 荷物が重すぎて、私一人では持とうにも持てなかった。
examples.romaji: Nimotsu ga omosugite, watashi hitori de wa motou ni mo motenakatta.
examples.english: The baggage was so heavy that I couldn't carry it by myself.

examples.japanese: 今朝、頭が痛くて、起きようにも起きられなかったんです。
examples.romaji: Kesa, atama ga itakute, okiyou ni mo okirarenakattan desu.
examples.english: This morning, I had a headache and couldn't manage to get up.

enhanced_notes.nuance: Expresses an impossibility, even if one tries, often with a negative undertone.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Use between verbs; the first verb in dictionary form, the second in negative ~ない form.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Common mistake is using negative form for both verbs, needs only in the second.
enhanced_notes.register: Often used in casual and informal settings; a bit harsh for formal conversation.

grammar.meaning: as this happens; following this; sometimes written in kanji

examples.japanese: 工事が進むにしたがって、建物の全体が見えてきた。
examples.romaji: Kouji ga susumu ni shitagatte, tatemono no zentai ga miete kita.
examples.english: As the construction progressed, the entire building became visible.

examples.japanese: 冬が近づいているに従って、気温が下がります。
examples.romaji: Fuyu ga chikazuite iru ni shitagatte, kion ga sagarimasu.
examples.english: As winter approaches, the temperature drops.

enhanced_notes.nuance: Used to show a direct consequential relationship between two circumstances, often implying the speaker's personal judgement or inference.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Works best with formal expressions and should be used in the middle of a sentence, not at the end.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Avoid using in casual or informal contexts, and do not confuse with 〜たがる which signifies someone else's wants or desires.
enhanced_notes.register: Primarily used in formal, academic, or written contexts or scenarios requiring respectful communication.

examples.japanese: 彼がうつ病になったのは努力の結果に他ならない。
examples.romaji: Kare ga utsu byou ni natta no wa doryoku no kekka ni hoka naranai.
examples.english: His becoming depressed is nothing but the result of his efforts.

examples.japanese: 両親が子供に淋しくするのは、子供を愛しているからに他ならない。
examples.romaji: Ryoushin ga kodomo ni sabishiku suru no wa, kodomo o aishite iru kara ni hoka naranai.
examples.english: The only reason parents make their children feel lonely is because of their love for them.

enhanced_notes.nuance: Expresses strong emphasis or confirmation about the only option or solution; can lend sternness or finality.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Use with nouns or noun phrases; not generally used in casual conversation due to its formal tone.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Avoid overuse, can make speech come off as overly dramatic or emphatic; inappropriate for informal contexts.
enhanced_notes.register: Formal or literary language; inappropriate for casual, informal speech.

grammar.meaning: read as あげく; after (in a troublesome/negative way)
grammar.notes: nouns need the の

examples.japanese: ５時間も話し合いを続けたあげく、何も決まらなかった。
examples.romaji: Gojikan mo hanashiai o tsuzuketa ageku, nani mo kimaranakatta.
examples.english: After discussing for five hours, we didn't decide on anything.

examples.japanese: 彼は散々悩んだ挙げ句、会社を辞めることに決めた。
examples.romaji: Kare wa sanzan nayanda ageku, kaisha o yameru koto ni kimeta.
examples.english: After much distress, he decided to resign from the company.

enhanced_notes.nuance: Emphasizes the final, often negative, outcome after a series of troubling events.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Usually used with a negative result, in the form 'Ta-form verb + 挙げ句'.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Not to be used with a positive outcome, it's a common mistake to confuse this usage.
enhanced_notes.register: Neutral to formal; can be used in both spoken and written Japanese, but avoid in casual conversations.

examples.japanese: これは現代の医学では、治しようがない病気だ。
examples.romaji: Kore wa gendai no igaku de wa, naoshiyou ga nai byouki da.
examples.english: This is a disease that modern medicine cannot cure.

examples.japanese: 台風で交通機関が全部止まっているので、学校に行きたくても生きようがない。
examples.romaji: Taifuu de koutsuu kikan ga zenbu tomatte iru node, gakkou ni ikitakute mo ikiyou ga nai.
examples.english: Due to the typhoon, all transportation has come to a halt, so even if I want to go to school, there's no way to get there.

enhanced_notes.nuance: Expresses deep desire, yet conveys an inability or impossibility to fulfill it.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Used with the verb in its masu-form, and often paired with negatives for full effect.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Learners often confuse it with ~たい, which only implies desire without the aspect of impossibility.
enhanced_notes.register: Mostly informal, but can be used in polite contexts to emphasize feelings of frustration or regret.

grammar.notes: noun needs である or の, adjective can use な or である

examples.japanese: ２月に桜が咲くわけがないよ。梅の花じゃない。
examples.romaji: Nigatsu ni sakura ga saku wake ga nai yo. Ume no hana janai.
examples.english: There's no way cherry blossoms would bloom in February. It's not a plum blossom, after all.

examples.japanese: 毎日遊んでばかりいたら、試験に合格するわけがない。
examples.romaji: Mainichi asonde bakari itara, shiken ni goukaku suru wake ga nai.
examples.english: If you just play around every day, there's no way you'll pass the exam.

enhanced_notes.nuance: Indicates a strong conviction that something cannot possibly be the case, often used to reject an opposing argument.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Use after the plain form of a verb, noun, or na-adjective.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Learners often improperly apply 〜わけがない directly to i-adjectives, which need to be turned into nouns first.
enhanced_notes.register: Common in both casual and formal language, but highly context-dependent.

grammar.meaning: god knows; how extremely this feeling/thought
grammar.notes: noun needs である, adjective can use な or である

examples.japanese: もう２年も家族に合っていない。家族は私のことをどんなに心配していることか。
examples.romaji: Mou 2 nen mo kazoku ni atte inai. Kazoku wa watashi no koto o donna ni shinpai shite iru koto ka.
examples.english: I haven't seen my family for already two years. I wonder how worried they must be about me.

examples.japanese: この曲が大好きだ。今まで何度聞いたことだろう。
examples.romaji: Kono kyoku ga daisuki da. Ima made nando kiita koto darou.
examples.english: I love this song. I wonder how many times I've listened to it so far.

enhanced_notes.nuance: Expresses strong feelings; often implying speculation or uncertainty.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Used with na-adjectives or nouns. Not used to make questions, despite containing 'darou'.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Incorrectly treating it as a question or using it with i-adjectives.
enhanced_notes.register: Mostly used in written language; formal and somewhat literary.

grammar.meaning: theres no doubt; I'm sure that; there's no mistaking
grammar.notes: noun and adjective need である

examples.japanese: アンナさんは日本生きて１０年になるとのことだから、ペラペラであるに違いない。
examples.romaji: Anna-san wa Nihon ikite 10-nen ni naru to no koto dakara, perapera de aru ni chigai nai.
examples.english: Since Anna has been living in Japan for ten years, she must be fluent in Japanese.

examples.japanese: 彼は足って泣いて、困っているに違いない。
examples.romaji: Kare wa naitte komatte iru ni chigai nai.
examples.english: He must be in trouble, crying and suffering.

enhanced_notes.nuance: 〜に違いない expresses a strong personal conviction, often used when speculating based on observable evidence.
enhanced_notes.usage_tips: Combine with 普通形 (plain form) of verbs, i-adjectives, na-adjectives and nouns; avoid using with definitive facts.
enhanced_notes.common_mistakes: Don't express doubt or probability; 〜に違いない affirms undeniable certainty.
enhanced_notes.register: More common in written contexts or formal speech; can sound overly assertive in casual conversation.
